div.head: PROVERBS and PARADOXES

Breaking forth in the day of Contention between the Parliament and Army, to prevent the dividing of the Army, and the Apparent Deluge of blood, ſo long endeavoured, and now brought to paſſe by the Jeſuite and Kings Party, uſing the Presbyterian and Parliament men, as the Monky the Catts Pavv, but hath lingred in the Birth by needleſſe Importunities, ſtepping into the Preſſ before them.

q.p: For the Tranſgreſſion of a Land many are the Princes thereof: but by a man of underſtanding and knowledge the State ſhall be prolonged.

div.head: I.
div.p: NOt Governours but Government is the delight or grievance of a Nation. Government.

div.head: II.
div.p: It is not a King, It is not a Parliament, It is not an Army that makes a Nation happy, if the Government be bad.

div.head: III.
div.p: Government is a Syſteme, or Body of Lawes, Statutes and Judgements, containing the duties both of Governours and Governed.

div.head: IV.
div.p: Good Government makes good Governours, and rejoyceth the Governed: Pro. 18.3. Pro. 28.4.12.15.28. Pro. 29.2.but bad Government maketh bad Governours, and the Governed mourn,

div.head: V.
div.p: Good Government is unchangeable, but bad Government, ſafety no longer then the Power of the Sword.

div.head: VI.
div.p: Good Government is only from God, but bad Government is only from men.

div.head: VII.
div.p: Governments invented by men, tend alwayes to their own Intereſt.

div.head: VIII.
div.p: When Governments depend on Governours, they laſt but a ſhore time of Life: the firſt part deducted for Incapacity, and the latter part oftentimes cut off for Diſabilitie, or Infidelity.

div.head: IX.
div.p: When Government depends on Governours, they change with every Perſon, and every Paſſion. New Lords, new Lawes.

div.head: X.
div.p: Government is more then Governours, as the whole is more then a part; when therfore Governours will bee greater then Government, Mat. 24 24. it ſwells them up into a bubble, and they break. Gnatts cannot ſwallow Camells.

div.head: XI.
div.p: When Governours will be greater then Government, they ſtreighten Government, and ſqueeſe the People, to the capacity and boudage of their Luſt.

div.head: XII.
div.p: Such Government diſquiets every ambitious Spirit, to contrive how he may get next into the Saddle, and his friends are Paraſites of the ſame mould, with their Attendants, fraud and cruelty.

div.head: XIII.
div.p: Governours and governed might make up a Government, as parts make up a whole. But becauſe Governours and governed can never meet together in one, nor agree together if met; therefore it is impoſſible for men to make a compleat Government, although when all is done, it were but humane, if God be left out, and far below the Government of God.

div.head: XIV.
div.p: The framing of a Government is called a Law-giving or Legiſlative power, but that (if good) is not in man. Legiſlative Power. Luc. 18.19.

div.head: XV.
div.p: He that wakes Lawes for men muſt be above man. And he that will make them perfect, muſt himſelf be without imperfection.

div.head: XVI.
div.p: A man cannot make a Law more perfect then himſelf. Nor impartial, becauſe he is a Party governing or governed.

div.head: XVII.
div.p: The Lawes of Medes and Perſians, and all the Governments of Arbens, Rome, and Venice, &c. were and are imperfect; ſome profane, ſome ſuperſtitious; Ours, All.

div.head: XVIII.
div.p: The man above man, Chriſt Jeſus is our one Law-giver, Ja. 4.12. who is able to ſave and to deſtroy.

div.head: XIX.
div.p: He is our King, he is our Law giver, he is our Judge, If. 33.22. he will ſave us.

div.head: XX.
div.p: They that will vie for Legiſlative power, muſt neceſſarily rival Jeſus Chriſt.

div.head: XXI.
div.p: They that will rival Jeſus Chriſt, can only do it in this life.

div.head: XXII.
div.p: The Legiſlative power of Jeſus Chriſt is only in this life, Heb. 9.27. 2 Cor. 5.10. Rev. 20.12. Mat. 16.27. 1 Cor. 15.28. for after death cometh Judgment, that every one may receive the things done in his body, to be judged out of thoſe things which are written in the Books, according to their works. And afterwards ſhall the Son himſelf be ſubject to the Father, that God may be All in All.

div.head: XXIII.
div.p: They that will Rival Jeſus Chriſt, or his Legiſlative power, muſt neceſſarily finde fault with Gods Law.

div.head: XXIV.
div.p: They that find fault ought to amend, and they that thinck to amend Gods Law, make themſelves wiſer then God.

div.head: XXV.
div.p: They that thinck themſelves wiſer then God, Prov. 26.12. are but ſo in their own conceit, and there is more hope of a Fool, for the fooliſhneſſe of God is wiſer then men. 1 Cor. 1.25.

div.head: XXVI.
div.p: The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge, Job 28.28. Prov. 1.7. Pſal. 119.98, 99; 100. his Commandments make us wiſer then our enemies, and give us more underſtanding, then our Teachers. The keeping of his Precepts make us underſtand more then the Ancient.

div.head: XXVII.
div.p: When men acknowledge God, then they are godly, no man doth acknowledge God that doth not obey his Law. 1 Jo. 2.3.

div.head: XXVIII.
div.p: His Law is perfect, LAW. Pſal. 19.7, 8, 9. his Statutes are right, his Judgments are true and righteous altogether. So that none may Dent. 4 2.12.32. Prov. 30.6. Rev. 22.18, 19. adde nor diminiſh. Nor Joſ. 1.7. Deut. 5.32.17.20.28.14. turn to the right hand, nor to the left. Nor have any Exod. 12.19, 49. Lev. 24.22. Numb. 15.16. Exod. 20.10.23.9.12. Lev. 16.29.17.12, 15, 18.26.19.10, 34.23.22.24.16.25.6.35.47, 48. Numb. 9.14.15.14, 15, 16, 26, 29, 30.19.10.35.15. Deut. 1.16.5.14.10.8, 19.14.21.17.15.23.7, 20.26.21. Deut. 29.11.31.12. Joſ. 8.33.20.9. other Law for the ſtranger, then for the homeborn.

div.head: XXIX.
div.p: The Law is a Royall Law, Ja. 2.8. Rom. 7.12, 14 Ja. 1.25. Ja. 2.10, 11. Spirituall, Holy, Juſt and Good. A perfect Law of Liberty, ſo perfect, that whoſoever ſhall keep the whole Law, and yet offend in one Point is guilty of all, and the reaſon is, becauſe that he that commanded one commanded all.

div.head: XXX.
div.p: Man cannot poſſibly invent another Law, ſave only in diſobedience, and oppoſition of the Law of God.

div.head: XXXI,
div.p: God himſelf keeps his own Law, and with all his Saints and Angells will keep them for ever in the Heavens.

div.head: XXXII.
div.p: By keeping this Law, the People of Iſrael were a peculiar Treaſure unto God above all People, Exod. 19.5, 6. Deut. 1.10. and were to be a Kingdome of Prieſts, and an holy Nation, and were multiplied as the Stars of Heaven, 1 King. 4.20. and as the Sand which is by the Sea for multitude, and were eating and drincking and making merry, 25. and they dwelt ſafely, every man under his Vine, and under his Figtree, and Silver was as the Stones in Jeruſalem, 1 Chron. 10.21.27. it was nothing accounted of.

div.head: XXXIII.
div.p: The People proſpered alwayes, and fared well, 1 King. 4. Joſ. 24.31.2.7. 2 King. 17.1. Chap. 23.24. Joſ. 2.11, 12, 13, 14, 15. keeping this Law, both in the time of Kings, and in the time of Judges; but they fared ill when they forſook it, both in the time of Kings, and in the time of Judges.

div.head: XXXIV.
div.p: The united Provinces, living under the ſhaddow of this Law, are multiplied exceedingly, and are eating and drincking and making merry, with great plenty of Gold, Silver, and all other abundance, proſpering in all their Labours, and fare better then all the Kingdomes, and Common-wealths in the whole World, if then we will envy them, and fare better then they, let us live up cloſer to theſe Lawes of God then they, and we ſhall proſper more then they.

div.head: XXXV.
div.p: The baſis of Tyrants Lawes, are Luſt and Selfwill. The baſis of Lawes by Parliament are Yeaes and Nayes.

div.head: XXXVI.
div.p: In what a tottering condition is that Nation, whoſe Being and well-Being depends upon the Ebbings and Flowings of YEA's and NAYES.

div.head: XXXVII.
div.p: Though men have not Legiſlative Power, Councill. yet Councill and Wiſdom is neceſſary to the Order and Execution of good Government.

div.head: XXXVIII.
div.p:
The wiſdom of a Nation is in chuſing a godly Councill, and the ſafety in a multitude of Counſellers: Pro. 11.14, 15, 22, 24, 26. where every mans Reaſon (like a publick Treaſure) contributes to ſafety, ſo they
be not executors of their own Counſells.

div.head: XXXIX.
div.p: The ſtrength of a Nation is in multitude of People, Pro. and the wealth of a Nation in frequent Trade and Traffique.

div.head: XL.
div.p: One chief Councill or Authority muſt be over all, for Appeales and Difficulties.

div.head: XLI.
div.p: As it is preſumption in the chiefeſt Councills to Rivall the Lord Jeſus Chriſt in his Legiſtative Power: ſo it is below them to deſcend to leſſe then appeales or the moſt difficult Caſe.

div.head: XLII.
div.p: When Supreme Councils are but repreſentatives of the People, it obligeth them to obey whom they repreſent, and be to them accomptable (which would be thought a ſoloeciſm) but if they judge for God, Deut 1.17. Deut. 17.19. they repreſent God, and ought to obey him, and be accomptable to him.

div.head: XLIII.
div.p: When Supreme Authority, Councill, and Governours, do not repreſent God, in judging for God, their higheſt title can be but to repreſent the people, though that be but a fallacie. For the people are never conſulted with, nor ſcarce ſuffered to petition. But the ſhadow will be more conſiderable then the ſubſtance. The Repreſentative will act both parts, diſpoſing of Eſtates, Lives and Liberties of the Repreſented and their Poſterities at pleaſure.

div.head: XLIV.
div.p: A wiſe Counſel eſtabliſh the People. But a fooliſh Counſel eſtabliſh themſelves.

div.head: XLV.
div.p:
Whether the Supreme Councel or Authority be few or many, or whether Appeals be to many or few, is not worth the diſpute, much leſſe one drop of blood, ſo a true Government be ſetled. For then an Elderſhip of ſeventy, or a Kingſhip of Solomon do alike make the people happy. Then the great diſpute o • Monarchy, Ariſtocracie, Democracie, Olygarehy, Polygarchie, Anarchie, (which affrightens the common people
like an exorciſm) do all fall to the ground as groundleſſe diſputes. Though all the quarrel hitherto hath bin, not What Government, but Who ſhall govern?

div.head: XLVI.
div.p: If the Supreme Authority be wicked, it is better have one Tyrant then many. If it be good, 1 Cor. 12.2 • . it is better have many helps then few, like two ſtrings to a Bowe.

div.head: XLVII.
div.p: The Election of Governours, Election. is given by God unto the people to have a ſhare in.

div.head: XLVIII.
div.p: The excellency of Venice, Deut. 1.13.16.18.17.15. Act. 6.3.and other places, is but the wiſdom and order of election.

div.head: XLIX.
div.p: As many are beſt for Counſel, ſo few for Order. Order.

div.head: L.
div.p: Want of order breeds confuſion; 1 Cor. 14.33. but God is the God of order.

div.head: LI.
div.p: It is a breach of Order to begin a ſecond buſineſſe, before the firſt be finiſhed. And to graſp at all, perfecteth nothing. For all cover, all loſe.

div.head: LII.
div.p: Where there is concord and unity in councel, there is ſtrength and honour. But where there is diſcord, there enters contention and ruine. Mat. 12.25. For a houſe divided cannot ſtand. Concordiâ parvae res creſcunt, diſc • rdiâ maxi ••• dilabuntur.

div.head: LIII.
div.p: Only through pride comes contention. Pro. 13.10.28.25.25.4. But take away the wicked from the Councel, and Government ſhall be eſtabliſhed.

div.head: LIV.
div.p: Whether Governours in Authority be few or many, Governours. they are but a part of Government.

div.head: LV.
div.p: Every man naturally affecteth Government, and would be alone, or (at leaſt) upper moſt.

div.head: LVI.
div.p: Every man by nature will be flattered and adored.

div.head: LVII.
div.p: Every mans way is right in his own eyes. Pro. 21.2. Pro. 12.15.14.12.26.25.

div.head: LVIII.
div.p: Till men can ſubmit to Government, they are not fit to be Governours.

div.head: LIX.
div.p: Such as the Governours are, ſuch are the People, whether it be to Wiſdom or Folly, Pro. 19.12. Vertue or Vice, Regis ad exemplum.

div.head: LX.
div.p: Ambitious Governours deſtroy the People, and covetous make them miſerable. We have had both.

div.head: LXI.
div.p: Unlimited Governours are like Lions let looſe into the Wilderneſſe of their own Paſſions, Pro. 28.15, 16. where Luſt (like hunger) minding them of their prey, they ſeize on all that is next them.

div.head: LXII.
div.p: Governours who are ſupreme above men, have none above them but God. If therefore they have not the Word of God to limit them, they grow boundleſſe.

div.head: LXIII.
div.p: Where Kings are Governours, 1 Sam. 8. 1 Pet. 2.13. Deut. 17.14, 20 they are ſupreme, yet they are limited by the Word of God. And the people are limited who deſire them.

div.head: LXIV.
div.p: When Kings forſook the Lawes of God they became Tyrants, Pro. 28.16. 1 Chro. 11.14. and God ſtirred up enemies againſt them, ſometimes ſtrangers, ſometimes their own people, ſometimes private men: For when Governours alter their Properties, they are no more Governours; no more then when a wiſe man becomes a fool or Madman, can be any longer a wiſe man.

div.head: LXV.
div.p: Whoſoever deſtroyed a Tyrant, was himſelf rewarded with their Crown, or might have been ſo rewarded.

div.head: LXVI.
div.p: Places make not men, but men make Places. Place.

div.head: LXVII.
div.p: Places make not men wiſe, nor honeſt, but diſcover what they are, Magiſtratus Oſtendit Virum, non facit.

div.head: LXVIII.
div.p: Men may be as wiſe and honeſt out of Councill as in Councill, out of Parliament as in Parliament.

div.head: LXIX.
div.p: A Fool in a wiſe mans place, a privat Spirit in a publick, Eccl. 10.6, 7, 17 Iſ. 1.23. Servants on Horſeback and Princes on Foot, and Princes to be companions of Theeves, loving Gifts, and following after rewards, makes a lean and deformed Common-wealth.

div.head: LXX.
div.p: Nevertheleſs, 1 Cor. 6.4. the leaſt eſteemed Chriſtian is ſufficient for a Judge, and the ſimpleſt meaning man for a witneſſe: ſince no man ought to witneſſe or judge beyond what he ſees or heares, Deut. 1.17. Lev. 19.15. unleſſe it be in diſcerning of a falſe witneſſe.

div.head: LXXI.
div.p: Governours are not Governours without a Sword, Sword. Rom. 13.4. nor ought they to wear it in vain, but to puniſh evill doers.

div.head: LXXII.
div.p: Againſt the Righteous man there ought to be no Sword, for the Law it ſelf is not made for a Righteous man. 1 Tim. 1.9.

div.head: LXXIII.
div.p: Every Sword is a Sword of Juſtice or Injuſtice, wherof the firſt is only of God.

div.head: LXXIV.
div.p: The ordinary Sword is for the Magiſtrate in time of Peace, the extraordinary for the Sold • er in time of Warr.

div.head: LXXV.
div.p: The abuſe or neglect of the Sword of Peace drawes forth the Sword of Warr, Eccl. 8.11. for becauſe Sentence againſt an evil work is not ſpedily executed, therfore the heart of the Sons of men is fully ſet in them to do evil.

div.head: LXXVI.
div.p: When offenders are greater and ſtronger then Magiſtrates, and do reſiſt them, then an Army performes the work of a Magiſtrate,

div.head: LXXVII.
div.p: When the War is ended, the Sword ought to be put up in a peaceful Scabbard.

div.head: LXXVIII.
div.p: An Army in time of Peace is a badge of ſlavery, which in time of war and danger is a means of deliverance and ſafety.

div.head: LXXIX.
div.p: Nevertheleſſe, when ſouldiers have done their work, they ought to be paid and cheriſhed.

div.head: LXXX.
div.p: When ſouldiers have purchaſed Freedom and Peace to a Nation, they ought not to be debarred of it themſelves. Nor ought to be disbanded till they are made capable of the ſame Peace and Freedom they have procured to others.

div.head: LXXXI.
div.p: Soldiers, Exod. 18.21. Deut. 1.15. who are Magiſtrates in time of Warr, may more eaſily be Magiſtrates in time of Peace. And as the Magiſtrates Sword neglected made the Soldiers, ſo the Soldiers Sword improved makes a Magiſtrate.

div.head: LXXXII.
div.p: The wiſdom and conduct of Warr is in the Officers, the ſtrength and execution in the privat Soldier.

div.head: LXXXIII.
div.p: There is as much reaſon or more to pay the privat Soldier, as the Officer, by how much his labour, danger, and want is greater.

div.head: LXXXIV.
div.p: There is as ſufficient ſubſiſtence for privat Soldiers in time of Peace as in time of Warr, and as all men fare better in time of Peace then Warr, ſo ought the privat Soldier.

div.head: LXXXV.
div.p: Sudden disbandings renew a Warr, or fill the high wayes with violence.

div.head: LXXXVI.
div.p: Warr is not ended till a Peace be ſetled, nor peace ſettled but by a true Government.

div.head: LXXXVII.
div.p: There can be no true Government by the enemies of Truth and Government.

div.head: LXXXVIII.
div.p: England hath many enemies, many ſuch enemies both powerfull and dangerous.

div.head: LXXXIX.
div.p: The dangerous enemies are at home, the powerfull are abroad.

div.head: XC.
div.p: The enemies abroad loſe their power, if we ſubdue or convert our enemies at home.

div.head: XCI.
div.p:
The enemies at home will never ceaſe ſo long as the contention
is about who ſhall Govern.

div.head: XCII.
div.p: If the Army are our Governours, they can reforme no more then the Parliament, till they have a better Rule then the Parliament to reforme by.

div.head: XCIII.
div.p: There can be no better Rule then the Rule in the Word of God.

div.head: XCIV.
div.p: God is able to overturn Armies as well as Kings, Parliaments, and Protectors.

div.head: XCV.
div.p: God will overturn Armies if they ſet up themſelves in the place of his Son Jeſus Chriſt.

div.head: XCVI.
XCVII.
div.p: If the Army Proclaim the Lawes of God, what man dares fight againſt the Lawes of God, though the Jeſuit and Lawyer together ſhould incourage them? for their own conſcience would ſight againſt them. Rom. 2.14.

div.head: XCVIII.
div.p: If the Army Proclaim not the Lawes of God, though they had the Ghoſt of Lycurgus, Numa Pompilius, and Mahomet to boot, and ſhould penn their Lawes from the Tongue of men and Angells, they ſhould neither ſatisfie the conſcience of their Friends, nor deterr the courage of their enemies. Gal. 1.8, 9.

div.head: XCIX.
div.p: What party ſoever (though a Kings party thus low, though a Parliaments party thus broken, though an Army party divided) ſhall firſt Proclaim the Lawes of God, with any probability of ſetling them, though they diſſemble, yet ſhall they prevail, by how much the very title of the quarrel is farr more high and honourable then all other titles whatſoever, and the burthen of mens Lawes ſo great? How much more if they mean in earneſt.

div.head: C.
div.p: The very title of the Lawes of God will unite all parties, but the wicked and prophane: and who would willingly hazard his Soul with the wicked and pr • phane?

div.head: CI.
div.p: The wicked and prophane (both unwiſe) will never ſett up the Lawes of God, Deut. 16.18. though the wicked and prophane dare never openly contradict them.

div.head: CII.
div.p: The ſeting up of the Lawes of God will ſettle Judges, Recorders, in every City or Town Corporate, whereby the Towne and Cities will be obliged, not only in conſcience, but in gratitude and ſenſe of their own benefit, to adhere to thoſe that ſhall firſt proclaim Gods Laws.

div.head: CIII.
div.p: The ſetting up of Judges and Recorders accordingly, will ſave above two or three millions to the people yearly, beſide Vexations and Troubles.

div.head: CIV.
div.p: The ſetting up the Laws of God, will ſettle all men in a peaceful Poſſeſſion of their own, whether it be Houſes, Land, or any other Poſſeſſion.

div.head: CV.
div.p: The ſetting up the Lawes of God, will take away the ſtrife of Titles and falſe witneſſe. Rewarding evil doers with the evil they meant to have done. Deut. 16.19.

div.head: CVI.
div.p: The ſetting up and proclaiming the Laws of God, need no other Councel then alone to proclaim them, being already penned by the Finger and Penman of God.

div.head: CVII.
div.p: The Curſes of the Law of God, Deut. 28. are provided for all thoſe that oppoſe the Laws of God: And the bleſſings for all thoſe that love and obey them.

div.head: Adde this after Proverb LX.
div.p: Supreme Officers ought to be changable, Mat. 7.12. Lue. 6.13. that they may equally ſhare in obedience as well as command, and not forget to do as they would be done by.

epigraph.q: Pſal. 68.1. Let God ariſe, let his enemies be ſcattered.
